articles.headline: Ohio, Long a Bellwether, Is Fading on the Electoral Map
articles.snippet: It is a jarring change for Ohio’s political veterans, who have long relished having their state at the center of the country’s presidential races.
articles.abstract: It is a jarring change for Ohio’s political veterans, who have long relished having their state at the center of the country’s presidential races.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS, Ohio — After decades as one of America’s most reliable political bellwethers, an inevitable presidential battleground that closely mirrored the mood and makeup of the country, Ohio is suddenly fading in importance this year.

articles.headline: Keep the Tax Returns, Trump; Just Give Us a Few Figures
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s adjusted gross income and actual federal taxes paid for the past five years are numbers that any taxpayer can understand.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s adjusted gross income and actual federal taxes paid for the past five years are numbers that any taxpayer can understand.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mr. Trump, I have a deal for you.

articles.headline: Wells Fargo’s Reaction to Scandal Fails to Satisfy Angry Lawmakers
articles.snippet: John Stumpf, the bank’s leader, told lawmakers the sham accounts were an ethical lapse limited to the 5,300 low-level employees, who were fired.
articles.abstract: John Stumpf, the bank’s leader, told lawmakers the sham accounts were an ethical lapse limited to the 5,300 low-level employees, who were fired.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He is forfeiting at least $41 million in pay. He vows that his bank will drop its sales incentive program — blamed for prompting bankers to set up illegal and unauthorized bank and credit card accounts to meet their sales goals — by the end of the week, not in January, as he had previously promised.

articles.headline: Och-Ziff to Pay Over $400 Million in Bribery Settlement
articles.snippet: OZ Africa Management, a unit of the hedge fund, pleaded guilty to bribing officials in Libya, Chad, Niger, Guinea and the Democratic Republic of Congo.
articles.abstract: OZ Africa Management, a unit of the hedge fund, pleaded guilty to bribing officials in Libya, Chad, Niger, Guinea and the Democratic Republic of Congo.
articles.lead_paragraph: Africa once represented a lucrative new market for a giant New York hedge fund.

articles.headline: Ex-Marine Describes Violent Hazing and the Lies That Covered It Up
articles.snippet: A top-notch recruit who was expelled from the Marines said his superiors told trainees to lie about punching, kicking and choking by drill instructors.
articles.abstract: A top-notch recruit who was expelled from the Marines said his superiors told trainees to lie about punching, kicking and choking by drill instructors.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUTNAM COUNTY, Fla. — In Marine Corps boot camp, Thomas Weaver learned to endure punches, kicks and choking by drill instructors in the Third Recruit Training Battalion at Parris Island, S.C. When one instructor repeatedly bashed his head against a doorway, he kept quiet and acted as if it were no big deal. But what he eventually could not take was the lying that covered up the abuse.

articles.headline: What Is Russia Up To, and Is It Time to Draw the Line?
articles.snippet: Russian airstrikes in Syria and cyberattacks have echoed some of the Cold War’s uglier moments. American intelligence officials wonder whether a grander scheme is at work.
articles.abstract: Russian airstrikes in Syria and cyberattacks have echoed some of the Cold War’s uglier moments. American intelligence officials wonder whether a grander scheme is at work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Escalating airstrikes in Syria. Sophisticated cyberattacks, apparently intended to influence the American election. New evidence of complicity in shooting down a civilian airliner.

articles.headline: Claims of Saudi Role in 9/11 Appear Headed for Manhattan Court
articles.snippet: Families of Sept. 11 victims are now able to pursue legal claims against the Saudis, and the legal battle could last for years.
articles.abstract: Families of Sept. 11 victims are now able to pursue legal claims against the Saudis, and the legal battle could last for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia paid millions of dollars to Washington lobbyists to keep it out of court. They have been unsuccessful. And now it is up to the kingdom’s lawyers to limit the damage.

articles.headline: World Leaders Gather to Mourn Shimon Peres, and Possibly His Dream
articles.snippet: President Obama and others paid homage to Mr. Peres’s tenacious search for reconciliation, yet the service made clear how elusive that idea has actually become in the Middle East.
articles.abstract: President Obama and others paid homage to Mr. Peres’s tenacious search for reconciliation, yet the service made clear how elusive that idea has actually become in the Middle East.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — From across the ocean and across the Green Line, they came on Friday to the mountaintop sanctuary of Mount Herzl to bid farewell to Shimon Peres, marking what one called the “end of the era of giants.” But the question of the moment was whether it was a funeral for a man or for his dream.

articles.headline: Immigrants Eager to Vote Obeyed All the Rules. It Didn’t Pay.
articles.snippet: Nearly a million legal immigrants applied for citizenship in the last year, causing an agency’s backlog to swell. Many will still be in the backlog on Nov. 8.
articles.abstract: Nearly a million legal immigrants applied for citizenship in the last year, causing an agency’s backlog to swell. Many will still be in the backlog on Nov. 8.
articles.lead_paragraph: They stayed up late studying for civics tests. They went to classes, paid hefty fees and underwent background checks.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Troubles Raise Fear of Global Shock
articles.snippet: As investors’ concerns of another crisis are stoked, the arithmetic is less important than fears about the impotence of European authorities.
articles.abstract: As investors’ concerns of another crisis are stoked, the arithmetic is less important than fears about the impotence of European authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Germany’s largest bank appears in danger, sending stock markets worldwide on a wild ride. Yet the biggest source of worry is less about its finances than a vast tangle of unknowns — not least, whether Europe can muster the will to mount a rescue in the event of an emergency.

articles.headline: China Manipulates Its Currency, but Not in the Way Trump Claims
articles.snippet: Various forces are trying to push down the value of the Chinese currency. But Beijing — in a reversal of previous policies — is trying to shore it up.
articles.abstract: Various forces are trying to push down the value of the Chinese currency. But Beijing — in a reversal of previous policies — is trying to shore it up.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In Monday’s presidential debate, Donald Trump repeated one of his frequent criticisms of China: It keeps its currency artificially cheap.

articles.headline: As America Sleeps, Donald Trump Seethes on Twitter
articles.snippet: In the predawn hours on Friday, the Republican presidential nominee took to Twitter to continue his attacks on both Hillary Clinton and Alicia Machado.
articles.abstract: In the predawn hours on Friday, the Republican presidential nominee took to Twitter to continue his attacks on both Hillary Clinton and Alicia Machado.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tweets started around 3:20 a.m. on Friday. Inside Trump Tower, a restless figure stirred in the predawn darkness, nursing his grievances and grabbing a device that often lands him in hot water.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Brands to Ad Agencies: Diversify or Else
articles.snippet: Concerned that agencies’ largely white and male leadership is hindering efforts to connect with American consumers, some companies threaten to walk.
articles.abstract: Concerned that agencies’ largely white and male leadership is hindering efforts to connect with American consumers, some companies threaten to walk.
articles.lead_paragraph: The advertising industry has tried for decades with little success to shed its “Mad Men”-like reputation as a profession dominated by white men. Now, some of the world’s biggest brands are viewing that lack of diversity as a liability.
